author: Philip Khoo
title: Visual communication for community
description: Information about Project Catalyst is difficult to digest for many. There is minimal good visual resources to explain complex concepts.

assessments.note: It is not clear how creating infographics to explain the insight sharing stage meets the challenge of improving distributed decision making.
assessments.reply: Information available in a variety of ways will increase participation and will therefore increase the ability for people to make better informed decisions. These are tools for the community.

assessments.note: The problem and solution statement are reasonable and are within the scope of the challenge. The use of infographics can be an important tool to improve the communication process regarding Catalyst and allow a better understanding of the calculations for defining the ranking of proposals in the voting app, it would be interesting to have at least 1 prototype of an infographic to demonstrate the concept more clearly. The idea has the potential to quickly improve voters' decision-making and improve understanding of Catalyst, as the development time is set at 10 weeks.

Information presented visually is much easier for humans to process. The proposal will improve the community's ability to stay informed and help new community members ingest information about Project Catalyst, enabling them to become active members more quickly without losing interest. This in turn will lead to the improvement of the whole Catalyst process. Less time spent on repeatedly answering the same questions will mean more time dedicated to other aspects of the process.

To my understanding, the proposal focuses on the generation of visual aids for Catalysts Community advisors. I believe I can foresee how the proposal could contribute to forward and improve distributed decision-making. Nevertheless, the proponent has not made it clear how he believes the visual resources created for the Catalyst Community Advisors could impact the broader issue of distributed decision-making for the whole community. The proposal would benefit from offering a brief description of the role and expected effect of the visual resources created for the Catalyst Community Advisors on the Distributed decision-making of the community. This brief description could be used by the proponent to demonstrate his understanding of the process within Catalyst and its articulation with the broader community. This brief description could further strengthen the proposal by demonstrating the communications skills necessary to explain the complex process involved in the Catalyst's assessments and their integration with the governance of the community at large.
assessments.reply: The point of the visual communications are to communicate the exact ideas that the CA is pointing out. The communications would not just describe CA processes but a whole range is concepts for the community to use to understand in a visual way.

assessments.note:
It's true that these information can be easily found through internet, however have them together in an easy display may cause the amount of people who actually finds them and understand them. Furthermore, more elucidated people allow better decisions to be made.
However, I am missing the metrics and goals to corroborate with the challenge.

Availability of a good infographic will be a good force multiplier in onboarding and help implicitly in decision making. The process and the number of funds are currently intimidating for new members and take some effort to understand.

This proposal will have a meaningful impact through the creation of infographics to support the catalyst community.  Although the content from the infographics will a rehash of Community information, it will enhance the visual appeal and understanding through the infographic.  To continual support the development of the proposal, additional funding would need to be provided to make changes and/or develop further.

The idea is very good, because in fact, the Catalyst system is very complex and diverse, and new members of the community may find it difficult to understand the parts that comprise it, as well as how they relate. I myself think that I would benefit from this project, because my entry into the community is recent, and even today I feel a little lost in relation to the whole. By understanding the parties better, new members (and old ones as well, if they have some better clarified concepts) will feel safer to make decisions and contribute in this way to Catalyst. Thus, the objectives of this challenge would be achieved.

Yes, the issue is clearly identified but more could be written about the issue in problem statement. Granted, someone familiar with the catalyst process would know what the proposer is talking about, from their own experience of being a CA.

I strongly support this proposal. Infograhics (especially dynamic ones) can very effectively support the life of Community Advisors AND VOTERS. I provided the following improvement ideas to this proposal during the feedback phase: 

"I would dream of a clustered project-funnel, which shown the various projects in its stages over their lifecycle, clustered according to the nature/scope of the project, maybe in COIN360.com style and e.g. colored according to ROI achievement (following different KPI mix along the life-cycle).
But maybe this is could be a direct IdeaScale feature, where active drill-down would be supported."
The proposer has the capability to deliver this task as detailed.

The proposer, Phil, is one of the most participative members in the Catalyst groups, has an excellent understanding of the process and already participates in the development of several projects for Catalyst improvements, such as the development of the Landing Page, tools for improvement in the assessments phase and collaboration in documentation development.

There is a link to Evgeniya Tranevskaya's Instagram, the designer who will be responsible for creating the art of the infographics, where we can see some of her works.

There is a reasonable plan, with a clear definition of timeline and budget.

The team producing the deliverables is without a doubt capable of producing compelling visuals, they have already proven this. I have no doubt about the successful production of the visual materials. I only have slight reservations about how those visuals will be distributed.

The proponent has demonstrated engagement with the community and participation in the processes that they are interested in supporting (Catalyst). Furthermore, the proponent provides examples of their own work and that of collaborators. Nevertheless, I  find that evidence and the plan presented insufficient to be confident of the successful execution of the project. In particular, I am concerned regarding the absence of evidence of previous successful execution and the little use of visual communication resources in the examples provided (Catalyst's landing page and teleolog web page). I found the following statement concerning: "A full list of proposed Infographic will be developed at the time of funding". The proponent has demonstrated experience with the process but nevertheless could not, or, chose not to, enunciate or demonstrate their understanding of the requirement for visual resources to explain it.  Furthermore, there are incomplete and undeveloped statements like "Look at build out a more detailed process of funding graphics and engaging a wider range of graphic designers - for future funding rounds.", which seems to be leftover from a previous assessment. With the experience of the proponent, this proposal would benefit greatly from a little bit more descriptiveness, i.e.: a more precise description of the deliverables to be expected.
It is true that during this assess the fund4 was not voted yet. Thus, I think that this art peace may be affected, since you gave no identification of the "themes" that would be shown.

The proposer has contributed to the development of a community website at a cost basis and his personal website claims experience in visual design. It is safe to assume that the proposer will be able to produce infographics of high quality.

The proposal is coming from a single individual who has more than enough technical and community involvement in the Catalyst space.  They have already worked with the Catalyst team to help develop and maintain documentation and infographics in the past.  The budget is a reasonable amount for the development project.

The author claims to have experience with business and design, as well as being a very active member of the Catalyst community. To carry out the assembly of the infographics itself, from what I understood, the designer @etranevskaya (her name was not said, but the profile on instagram) would be responsible. In relation to design, the professional to be well prepared, talented and capable, according to their work posted on the social network. However, in relation to the selection of information that would be included in the graphics, I think it would be safer if someone specializing in blockshain were hired as well. Because despite being very involved with Catalyst, it is not certain that the author has deep experience in cryptocurrencies. In my opinion, the ideal would be: to keep the designer, hire someone for Motion Design (as he also mentions), keep the author and hire a specialist in blockshain / ADA.
Yes, the proposer had made his/her expertise clear in the relevant experience and 'about me' sections and provided links to portfolio of work so a reader can check.

Philip is a very active member of the CATALYST Community and has impressively demonstrated his capabilities and 'full-hearted engagement.' He has succeeded to become part of a wider team of activists, so that the continuous discussions will help to further optimize his proposal 'on the job'. The outlined costs for this proposal are VERY reasonable, I have no doubt that this produces great ROI.
More information is need to explain why how this proposal meets the challenge. Whilst infographics might be nice to have, why are they integral to the challenge and a best use of limited funds.

The problem and solution described are in line with the challenge. The proposal does not involve great complexity and the roadmap and milestones described are clear enough to allow auditing of the proposal.

There are details about the proposer, his experiences and qualifications, information about the designer's portfolio and details about budget allocation.

There are no elements / KPIs that allow us to understand what the impact on the community's decision-making was.

My only concern is that there is no concrete plan to effectively get the infographics in front of the people who would need to see them. Producing compelling and informative visuals is only part of the story, distributing them successfully is what will actually improve the Catalyst experience and lead to more informed, better decisions by the community.

Given the nature of the proposal, it is very feasible. The proposal constitutes in essence a graphic design contract. I believe there are commercial standards to identify how much work would be necessary to execute the proposal, what results should be expected, and at what cost. Unfortunately, the proposal does not provide sufficient information to assess how effectively it addresses the challenge. As I have mentioned in the previous two items of this assessment, the proposal would benefit from a description of how the proponent envisions the visual resources for the Catalyst Community Advisors  would contribute to the broader decision making of the community and, in doing this, the proponent could demonstrate his experience with Catalyst and the community, and as a graphic designer by, at least, listing preliminary the "infographic" that they believe would be necessary to achieve their goal.
It is missing metrics and KPI, mainly, and the themes which will be aborded are not described.
The proposal is simple, straight forward for audit and track progress. Each infographic provided can be used as a simple measure of progress.

There is a defined roadmap with a scheduled delivery cadence in the plan to generate the infographics.  The problem is clearly understood to help support Community documentation with east-to-read infographics and an additional buffer for delivery is included in the plan.

For example: it is said that the intention is to make 2 charts per week, for 10 weeks. But which subjects would be covered in each graph, exactly? There are many topics to be addressed, it would certainly be beneficial to clarify better how and in what order they would be addressed. Another point that I thought was that it is not said where these graphics would be available, how they would reach the public, since the ultimate goal is to better guide the members of the community. Regarding the division of expenses, it is said that an amount would be shared in 50/50 for the designer and the author, who would do the research. But for example, if someone else was also hired, that account would need to be rethought. Suggestion: 50% for the designer and 25% for each researcher, because the work of visual assembly is very complex (I am currently a graduate student in design) and would have to be done by a single person, whereas the research would be divided.
The information on success criteria and measuring milestones is a bit unclear to me and could do with expanding somewhat

Good information added for providing basic audibility. Nevertheless, I give more weight to the fact that Philip is quite active and entangled with the CATALYST Community, so that this proposal will not only be audited based on formal milestones, but also in ongoing interactions with a lot of other knowledgeable activists.

solution: Create visual resources to continue the series of info graphics that visually describe Project Catalyst from Fund 3.
experience: Community advisor from fund 3. Fund 4 proposal Infographic Series 1 https://bit.ly/3dVhfhV, Community Landing Page https://cardanocataly.st/
